Award.AwardTitle: REU site: Great Lakes Educational Exchange (GLEE) at the University at Buffalo, State University of New York
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site for the summers of 2013-2015 led by Janet Morrow and Sarbajit Banerjee of the University at Buffalo, State University of New York. The Site will support ten students per summer for a ten week program. The Site will focus on interdisciplinary collaborative research with an emphasis on sustained engagement throughout the academic year. A special thrust will focus on recruiting at least two community college students each summer to provide them access to research opportunities at an early stage of their career. Broader impacts stem from the introduction of students to modern research methods and projects. Collaborative research activities during the academic year will promote student involvement in the organization of data in presentations and manuscripts. The Site will focus on students who may not normally have the chance to participate in research in a large university setting and increase the likelihood of their participation in graduate-level science and engineering programs.

Interdisciplinary research projects are available in several areas; including, 1) synthesis and characterization of nanomaterials, 2) organic synthesis, 3) chemical biology/medicinal chemistry, 4) environmental chemistry, 4) computational chemistry, 5) polymer and materials chemistry, and 6), inorganic materials for biomedical diagnostics and imaging. Participants will meet weekly as a group for discussions on laboratory safety, manuscript writing, research ethics, graduate education and career choices. Students will also hear from industrial researchers through a biweekly seminar series, which will provide further exposure to career choices. Students will have multiple opportunities to present their work in oral and written communication in the summer program and at professional society meetings. Additional activities will include field trips to local industries and research centers across Western New York's thriving manufacturing, life science, and biomedical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site, Great Lakes Educational Exchange (GLEE) at the University at Buffalo, State University of New York, accepted thirty-six undergraduate students as REU fellows over a three summer period.  Students came from 25 different institutions across the country including community colleges.   

Students conducted research in several areas of chemistry and worked with faculty and graduate student mentors on an original research project for ten weeks.  The intellectual merit of the program was based on the research projects.  Project topics included theoretical calculations on solids, studies on enzymes, polymers, magnetic resonance imaging contrast agents, fluorescent nanoparticles for sensors, environmental projects that tracked hormones in livestock, metal ion binding to DNA, metal organic framework solids, photodynamic therapy agents, sensitized solar cells, and vanadium-based nanowires for glass coatings.  In addition to experimental work, students were trained in presenting their research and in writing about their research.  Many of the students published abstracts or articles on their research.  Several students continued their research projects with faculty at their home institutions in the area during the academic year.     

For additional career development, several industries that employ chemists were visited including: St. Gobain (materials), Life technologies (analytical, biological media), Honeywell (fluorinated refrigerants, polymers), New Era Cap (materials), and Tapecon (materials).  Industrial scientists gave presentations and tours to inform the students about skills required for jobs in their companies.

Broader impacts included training of students in multidisciplinary chemistry research and career development. The majority of the fellows (>80%) are continuing studies in graduate school or professional schools.  The REU site enabled the training of a talented pool of chemistry students who lacked prior research experience. In addition, ties were strengthened to faculty members in neighboring four year colleges by the incorporation of collaborative research projects into the REU program.
